p.s: The given excerpt to be analyzed can be consideres the turning point of the play undelining the consequences of suppressing his identity to assimilate into a new society completely.
Many events and conflicts are the reason for Amir to exploseexplode completely leading to the loss of his mind.
One important event clearly is JorysJory's promotion at their work (cf. p. 71, ll. 23).
His disrespectful way to talk expresses Amir's anger about it asking Who are you? (p. 71, l. 25).
While Jory is shocked about seeing Isaac and Emily kissing each other, he still rages about their boss promoting Jory in his place (cf. p. 72, l. 18).
The author underlines Amir's anger using the expression vicious in the stage direction (p. 72, l. 17).
As Jory only focusses on the current happening Amir [exploses] canalyzingcanalizing his anger (p. 72, l. 21).
He talks about the mistreatment at the jewishJewish law office where he works.
They gave him the closet at the end of the hall [where] [the office] [keeps] the cleaning supplies whereas Jory got one with a great view (p. 72, ll. 22).
Amir mentions the mistreatment asking You think you're the nigger here? answering with I'm the nigger!Me! (p. 72, l. 29).
Akhtar points out the systemic discrimination against Muslims in America after 9/11.
He expresses how the time changed.
Jory, who is afro-americanAfro-American, is treaten better than Amir, a South Asian looking man.
It also shows the problems between religions in this case Islam and Jewry.
Amir's experiences at work definetelydefinitely are an event for his outburst.
As the scene's tension raises higher the conflict between the four protagonists comes to a highlight.
As Amir and Isaac are facing off he spits in Isaac's face which is a sign of antisemitism (cf. p. 72, ll. 39).
This is the first moment Amir loses his control.
He was brought up with antisemitism by his mother who spat in his face as he told her he likes a jewishJewish girl as a child.
Amir spitting in Isaac's face shows that even if you try to get rid of something you was brought up with like Amir it still consists in you.
Isaac, who is jewishJewish, discriminates Amir in the following: There is a reason why they call you people animals (p. 73, l. 1).
A different conflict is Jory hurting and provocating Amir as her and Isaac leave.
She mentions that Mort, their boss, will retire promoting Jory for this job (cf. p. 73, ll. 4).
She goes on that Mort chose her because he thinks Amir is duplicitous and it's impossible to trust [him] (p. 73, l. 9).
The following pause increases the power of JorysJory's words expressing Amir is hardly affected by it.
He probably thought he could trust Mort because he was a good friend ending in not answering AmirsAmir's calls.
Right as the reader thinks the tension lowers Amir's anger is building up again (cf. p. 73, ll. 16).
The protagonist is in a really hard situation emotionlyemotionally as he realizes his wife may cheatscheat on him.
He asks her in a vulnerable, intense tone if she sleeps with Isaac (p. 73 ll. 26).
The meaning and power of this question and its following answer is underlined by a pause (cf. p. 73 l. 28).
As Emily stops refusing her affair he completely loses his mind hitting her three times in the face (cf. p. 74).
The events and conflicts already mentioned were leading up to Amir's outbursts and his loss of control.

The torrent of rage, overtaking him followed by uncontrolled violence as brutal as it needs to be in order to convey the discharge of a lifetime of discreetly building resentment is the consequence of those events (p. 74 ll. 6).
But it are not just the events leading to this turning point of the play.
His whole life Amir tried to cover up his origin and his former religion to assimilate completely into the americanamerican society.
As a result he lost his identity and had to suppress it his whole life.
All the things he suppressed as well as everything he had to deal with (prejudices) justified his outbreak.
Supported by drinking alcoholic drinks.
As Amir comes back to his senses he says oh my God, referring ot a higher power to find help for his behaviour (cf. p. 74, l. 13).
The negative influence he described the Islam with are representing his behaviour in this excerpt.
This could be an indication that Amir uses the impact of religion as an excuse for his own cruelty.
To come to a conclusion one can say that Amir shows his real personality in the given excerpt loosinglosing the control over his personality he suppressed before.
